In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia function that accomplishes what you've described:

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int=3)
    if typeof(dt) != DateTime
        throw(ArgumentError("Input must be of type DateTime"))
    end
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```
This function first checks the type of `dt`. If it is not a DateTime object, it throws an error. If `dt` is a DateTime object, it increments the time by `bump` hours (which defaults to 3 if not specified). The return value of the function is the new DateTime object with the added hours.
